questions.text: While monitoring a case of laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the End tidal Carbon di oxide monitor shows a change in the pattern as shown in the figure. What does it signify ?
questions.solution:
• Curare cleft:
    • Occurs when a patient on controlled ventilation exhibits spontaneous respiratory activity.
    • Typically seen in the late expiratory phase of the capnography waveform.
    • Caused by incomplete neuromuscular blockade or the patient's recovery from paralytic agents like curare.

Why Not Other Options

  • B) Tube obstruction:
    • Would result in a decreased or flattened capnography waveform, indicating airway resistance.
  • C) Hypercarbia:
    • Would show a steady rise in the EtCO2 values but not a cleft or notch.
  • D) Endobronchial migration of the tube:
    • Leads to an abrupt change in the waveform, usually reduced EtCO2 due to one-lung ventilation.

Key Takeaways

  • Curare cleft indicates the return of spontaneous breathing efforts in a paralyzed patient, seen on capnography as a characteristic notch in the expiratory phase.
  • Proper interpretation of capnography waveforms helps monitor ventilation adequacy and detect complications during surgery.

questions.text: The given image is modality of neuromonitoring, that helps in estimating the depth of anaesthesia administered to a patient.
questions.solution:
• Bispectral monitoring (BIS) is used for continuous assessment of anaesthesia depth, by analyzing EEG data and providing a numerical value (0-100).
  • BIS values of 40-60 indicate the optimal depth of general anaesthesia, where the patient is unconscious with minimal chance of recall.
  • A BIS below 40 suggests deep sedation, while a BIS near 0 reflects complete brain inactivity (isoelectric EEG).
  • BIS helps adjust anaesthetic dosage, minimizing risk of awareness or excessive sedation.

Why Not Other Options:

  • B) Infrared oximetry: Measures oxygen saturation in the blood, not related to anaesthesia depth or consciousness.
  • C) TOF ratio: Refers to train-of-four monitoring, which assesses neuromuscular blockade, unrelated to depth of anaesthesia.
  • D) Electroencephalogram (EEG): Records brain electrical activity, but unlike BIS, it is not a simplified or processed method to monitor anaesthesia depth in real-time.

Key Takeaways:

  • BIS is used to monitor anaesthesia depth, with values of 40-60 being optimal for unconsciousness.
  • BIS helps prevent under or over-sedation by adjusting anaesthetic doses.
  • Other methods like TOF and oximetry do not assess anaesthesia depth.

questions.text: The picture demonstrates Neuromuscular monitoring, identify the peripheral. Nerve stimulated:
questions.solution:
• Ulnar nerve is the most commonly monitored nerve in neuromuscular monitoring because it leads to contraction of the adductor pollicis muscle (thumb).
  • Stimulation can occur at the wrist, elbow, or hand, with electrodes placed along the medial aspect of the distal forearm, about 2 cm proximal to the skin crease.
  • Thumb adduction is the observed response due to contraction of the adductor pollicis muscle, ensuring reliable neuromuscular function assessment.
  • Ulnar nerve stimulation is preferred because it minimizes the chance of direct muscle stimulation, providing more accurate monitoring results.

Why not others:

  • Radial nerve: Stimulates wrist extension, not thumb adduction, making it unsuitable for monitoring.
  • Median nerve: Causes finger flexion and thumb opposition, which does not align with neuromuscular monitoring goals.
  • Axillary nerve: Innervates the deltoid muscle, causing shoulder abduction, not typically monitored for anaesthesia depth.

Key Takeaways:

  • Ulnar nerve stimulation, causing thumb adduction, is the most accurate and widely used site for neuromuscular monitoring, ensuring minimal direct muscle stimulation and reliable responses.

questions.text: According ASA standards of monitoring , the following monitors are mandatory except
questions.solution:
• TEE (Transesophageal echocardiography) is not mandatory for routine monitoring according to ASA standards. It is typically used in specific cases, such as cardiac surgeries, to monitor heart function in real-time.
  • ASA mandates the use of oxygenation (pulse oximeter), ventilation (EtCO2), circulation (ECG, HR, NIBP every 5 minutes), and temperature monitoring during anaesthesia to ensure patient safety.
  • These monitors help detect complications early, allowing for prompt intervention and improving patient outcomes.

Why Not Others:

  • A) Blood Pressure (NIBP): This is a standard ASA requirement, monitored every 5 minutes, to track hemodynamic stability.
  • B) ECG: Mandatory for continuous monitoring of heart rate and rhythm, identifying arrhythmias or ischemic changes.
  • D) EtCO2 (End-tidal CO2): Required for assessing ventilation, confirming proper airway management, and detecting hypoventilation or hyperventilation.

Key Takeaways:

  • TEE is not part of the basic ASA monitoring standards but can be used for specific, high-risk cases like cardiac surgery.
  • Oxygenation, ventilation, circulation, and temperature are the key elements monitored during all anaesthetic procedures according to ASA standards.
  • Continuous monitoring is crucial for ensuring patient safety, early detection of complications, and guiding anaesthetic management during procedures.

questions.text: CVP line was secured in right Interal Jugular vein for inotropic support during early sepsis when the patient got admitted. Now he is completely stable and planned for discharge the next day. As a JR in the department you were asked to remove the central line, what is the optimal position that is recommended for removal of the central line
questions.solution:
• The head-down position increases venous pressure at the site of central line removal, which helps prevent air aspiration into the vein, thereby reducing the risk of air embolism.
  • After removing the catheter, external pressure should be maintained on the site for approximately 5 minutes to facilitate clot formation and seal the vessel, preventing bleeding.
  • Positioning the patient in a head-down position aids in venous return, especially in patients who may have low blood volume or are hypotensive, ensuring adequate perfusion and stability during the procedure.

Why Not Others:

  • A) Sitting position: While it is often used, it does not provide the same advantages as the head-down position, particularly in preventing air embolism.
  • B) Can be removed in any position: This is incorrect as specific positioning significantly mitigates the risks associated with line removal.
  • C) Prone position: This is inappropriate for central line removal as it complicates access to the catheter site and poses a risk of obstruction or injury.

Key Takeaways:

  • The head-down position is crucial for safely removing a central venous line to enhance venous pressure and minimize the risk of complications such as air embolism.
  • External pressure should be applied to the site for about 5 minutes after removal to ensure proper hemostasis.
  • Recognize the potential complications of central venous access, which include:
    • Air embolism: Occurs if air enters the venous system during removal.
    • Bleeding: Risk of bleeding from the site if not properly managed.
    • Dysrhythmias: May occur due to irritation of cardiac tissues during catheter manipulation.
    • Infection: Always consider the risk of introducing infection when manipulating a central line.

questions.text: The esophageal temperature sensor should be positioned at
questions.solution:
• Esophageal temperature sensors provide accurate core temperature readings and are often included in esophageal stethoscopes.
  • Optimal Positioning: The sensor should be placed in the lower third of the esophagus. This positioning:
    • Ensures that the sensor is located behind the heart, allowing it to reflect core body temperature accurately.
    • Avoids interference from the temperature of tracheal gases, which can occur if positioned higher in the esophagus.
    • Aligns with the area where heart sounds are most pronounced, enhancing the effectiveness of temperature monitoring.
  • Common Monitoring Sites: Other common sites for temperature monitoring include:
    • Tympanic membrane
    • Nasopharynx
    • Bladder
    • Rectum
    • Skin

Why Not Others:

  • A) Upper third of the esophagus: This position may capture temperatures influenced by inhaled gases, leading to inaccurate readings.
  • B) Middle third of the esophagus: While this could provide a decent reading, it is less effective than the lower third for core temperature accuracy.
  • D) Just near the esophagus: This is too vague and does not specify a proper location for accurate temperature monitoring.

Key Takeaways:

  • Lower third of the esophagus is the recommended position for esophageal temperature sensors to obtain accurate core temperature readings.
  • Temperature monitoring is essential during anaesthesia to prevent complications related to hypothermia (delayed drug metabolism, impaired coagulation, increased infection risk) and hyperthermia (tachycardia, neurological injury).
  • Continuous temperature monitoring helps assess the quality of anaesthesia and patient safety throughout the surgical procedure.

questions.text: The core body temperature reaches the steady state during
questions.solution:
• Core Temperature Dynamics:
    • Core temperature generally reflects central venous blood temperature except during rapid changes (e.g., extracorporeal perfusion).
    • During Phase 1, core temperature usually decreases by 1°C to 2°C within the first hour of general anaesthesia due to heat redistribution from central (warm) areas (abdomen, thorax) to peripheral (cool) tissues (arms, legs) caused by anaesthetic-induced vasodilation.
    • In Phase 2, there is a gradual decline in temperature over the next 3 to 4 hours.
    • Phase 3 represents the point at which core temperature reaches a steady state, where heat loss equals metabolic heat production.
  • Hypothalamic Regulation:
    • In unanesthetized patients, the hypothalamus regulates core temperature within narrow tolerances, known as the interthreshold range.
    • This regulation involves thresholds for:
      • Sweating and vasodilation at one extreme.
      • Vasoconstriction and shivering at the other extreme.

Why Not Others:

  • A) Phase 1: Represents initial temperature drop due to redistribution, not steady state.
  • B) Phase 2: Involves a slower decline in temperature, but not yet at steady state.
  • D) Phase 4: This phase typically does not apply to the described temperature dynamics; the steady state is established in Phase 3.

Key Takeaways:

  • The steady state of core body temperature occurs during Phase 3 of anaesthesia.
  • Heat redistribution and environmental heat loss are significant factors in temperature changes during anaesthesia.
  • Proper temperature management is crucial to prevent complications related to hypothermia or hyperthermia during surgical procedures.

questions.text: The arterial pressure transducer is zeroed at the level of
questions.solution:
• Zeroing the Transducer: The arterial pressure transducer must be zeroed at the level of the right atrium for accurate readings. This ensures that the pressure measured reflects the true hemodynamic status of the patient.
  • Calibration Process:
    • A stopcock is opened at the level of the right atrium, typically aligned with the midaxillary line, and the zero trigger on the monitor is activated.
    • If the patient's position changes (e.g., the operating table is raised or lowered), the transducer must be repositioned or zeroed again to maintain accuracy.
  • Positioning Considerations: In a seated patient, cerebral pressure can differ from left ventricular pressure. Therefore, the transducer may need to be zeroed at the level of the ear to approximate the circle of Willis for more accurate brain pressure readings.

Why Not Others:

  • A) Abdominal aorta: This is too low for accurate central venous pressure measurements.
  • C) Epigastrium: This position is also too high to accurately represent the right atrium's pressure.
  • D) Kidney: Similar to the abdominal aorta, this position does not accurately reflect the central venous pressure.

Key Takeaways:

  • The correct zeroing of the arterial pressure transducer at the right atrium is crucial for accurate blood pressure monitoring.
  • Changes in patient positioning require recalibration to maintain measurement accuracy.
  • Invasive arterial monitoring is indicated for patients with hypotension, significant blood pressure fluctuations, or the need for frequent blood analyses.

questions.text: Most commonly chosen leads for monitoring patients during perioperative period
questions.solution:
• Lead II:
    • Provides the largest P-wave voltages due to its orientation (approximately 60° from the right arm to the left leg), parallel to the electrical axis of the atria.
    • It enhances the detection of arrhythmias and inferior wall ischemia.
  • Lead V5:
    • Positioned over the fifth intercostal space at the anterior axillary line, it is effective for monitoring anterior and lateral wall ischemia.
    • Historically shown to be the most sensitive single lead for detecting ischemia, especially during exercise stress testing and under anaesthesia.

Both leads should be monitored simultaneously to provide comprehensive cardiac monitoring during the perioperative period.

Why Not Others:

  • A) Lead I and II: While Lead I provides useful information, it does not enhance ischemia detection as effectively as Lead V5.
  • B) Lead I and III: Lead III has limited utility in monitoring ischemia compared to Lead V5.
  • D) Lead III and V4: Lead V4 is useful, but Lead II offers better insights into atrial activity and arrhythmias.

Key Takeaways:

  • Lead II and V5 are preferred for perioperative monitoring due to their ability to detect both arrhythmias and ischemia effectively.
  • Proper lead selection is crucial for accurate cardiac monitoring and early detection of potential complications during surgery.

choices.text: C waves are due to tricuspid valve elevation
V waves reflect venous return against a closed tricuspid valve
X and y descents are caused by the upward displacement of the tricuspid valve during systole

questions.text: All are true regarding the central venous waveform except
questions.solution:
• A Waves:
    • Result from atrial contraction.
    • Absent in atrial fibrillation and exaggerated in junctional rhythms (cannon a waves).
  • C Waves:
    • Caused by tricuspid valve elevation during early ventricular contraction.
  • V Waves:
    • Reflect venous return against a closed tricuspid valve.
  • X and Y Descents:
    • The x descent is due to the downward displacement of the tricuspid valve during ventricular systole.
    • The y descent occurs due to the tricuspid valve opening during diastole.

Why Not Others:

  • A: True; a waves are a normal feature of the waveform.
  • B: True; c waves correspond to the elevation of the tricuspid valve.
  • C: True; v waves indicate venous return against a closed tricuspid valve.

Key Takeaways:

  • Understanding the central venous waveform is crucial for interpreting cardiac dynamics.
  • Each component of the waveform (a, c, v waves, and x/y descents) provides valuable information about cardiac function and valvular mechanics.
  • Misinterpretation of the x and y descents can lead to incorrect conclusions regarding heart function and hemodynamics.

questions.text: A 70 year old male patient with history of chronic hypertension, undergoes surgery for benign prostatic hypertrophy, under spinal anaesthesia. In the middle of the surgery patient develops TURP syndrome, the following are manifestations of TURP syndrome except
questions.solution:
• Hyperglycemia (not hypoglycemia) is a relevant concern, particularly with the absorption of glycine-based irrigating solutions during transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP).
  • TURP Syndrome is characterized by:
    • Circulatory fluid overload.
    • Water intoxication.
    • Toxicity from solutes in the irrigating fluid.
  • Common Symptoms:
    • Headache.
    • Restlessness.
    • Confusion.
    • Cyanosis.
    • Dyspnea.
    • Arrhythmias.
    • Hypotension.
    • Seizures.
  • Incidence: Less than 1%. Symptoms can manifest intraoperatively or postoperatively and can be rapidly fatal.

Why Not Others:

  • B: Hypoosmolarity is a typical manifestation due to fluid overload.
  • C: Hyponatremia occurs as a result of dilution from absorbed irrigation fluids.
  • D: Hypothermia can occur due to prolonged surgical procedures, especially in a regional anaesthesia context.

Key Takeaways:

  • TURP syndrome results from systemic absorption of irrigation fluid during prostate surgeries, leading to severe complications.
  • Understanding the signs and symptoms is crucial for early identification and management to prevent severe outcomes.
  • Preventative measures include using isotonic solutions, monitoring fluid absorption, and limiting irrigation time and pressure to reduce risks associated with TURP syndrome.

questions.text: A 40 year old man was given spinal anaesthesia by first year anaesthesia resident for inguinal hernia repair. After 5mins, patient becomes unconscious, apneic with hypotension. Here the apnoea is due to
questions.solution:
• High Spinal Anaesthesia:
    • The condition suggests a high spinal block resulting in:
      • Severe hypotension due to widespread vasodilation.
      • Bradycardia from involvement of T1-T4 fibers.
      • Respiratory insufficiency as the block ascends to affect the cervical spinal cord.
  • Apnea Mechanism:
    • Primarily due to hypoperfusion of the medulla from significant hypotension.
    • Less likely to be caused directly by phrenic nerve paralysis.
  • Clinical Considerations:
    • Recognizing symptoms of a total spinal where cranial nerve involvement occurs.
    • Anterior spinal artery syndrome may occur due to prolonged hypotension with elevated intraspinal pressure.
  • Immediate Management:
    • Ensure adequate arterial oxygenation and ventilation.
    • Intubation and mechanical ventilation may be necessary for severe respiratory failure.
    • Intravenous vasopressors and rapid IV fluid administration for hypotension.
    • Atropine for bradycardia; ephedrine or epinephrine may be used to enhance heart rate and blood pressure.

Why Not Others:

  • A: Involvement of T1-T4 fibers generally leads to bradycardia, not primarily apnea.
  • B: Failure to connect oxygen is not a primary cause of unconsciousness and hypotension in this scenario.
  • C: Malingering is unlikely given the abrupt change in the patient's condition.

Key Takeaways:

  • High spinal anaesthesia can rapidly lead to severe complications, necessitating prompt intervention.
  • Recognizing signs of medullary hypoperfusion is critical for timely management.
  • Comprehensive monitoring and readiness to support ventilation and circulation are essential during spinal anaesthesia procedures.

questions.text: A 60 year old male with history hypertension, on propranolol, undergoes elective cholecystectomy. The patient is anaesthetized with propofol, fentanyl, sevoflurane and vecuronium. Procedure went uneventful and patient was reversed with pyridostigmine and atropine with weight appropriate doses. Patient was extubated and shifted to post anesthesia care (PACU) unit. One hour after arrival to PACU, patient heartrate decreases from 90 to 40beats/min. which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
• Pyridostigmine Effects:
    • An acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that reverses neuromuscular blockade.
    • Commonly causes muscarinic side effects like bradycardia if not adequately countered with an anticholinergic.
    • Has a longer duration of action compared to other similar agents.
  • Anticholinergic Co-administration:
    • Atropine is often used to counteract muscarinic effects; however, it has a shorter duration.
    • Once atropine's effects wear off, the bradycardia from pyridostigmine becomes prominent, especially in this patient with preexisting cardiac issues.
  • Clinical Consideration:
    • Glycopyrrolate is preferred over atropine for patients with cardiac disease due to its longer duration.
    • The need for proper timing and dosing of anticholinergics is critical in managing bradycardia associated with pyridostigmine use.

Why Not Others:

  • B: Delayed effect of fentanyl is less likely as fentanyl typically does not cause bradycardia unless there is significant overdose.
  • C: Propranolol can cause bradycardia, but the timing after reversal indicates pyridostigmine as the more likely cause.
  • D: Recurarization is unlikely as the patient was adequately reversed with appropriate doses.

Key Takeaways:

  • Co-administration of Anticholinergics: Essential when using acetylcholinesterase inhibitors like pyridostigmine to mitigate bradycardia.
  • Monitoring Cardiac Function: Particularly in patients with preexisting conditions, is crucial following the administration of neuromuscular reversal agents.
  • Understanding Pharmacodynamics: Highlights the importance of matching the duration of action of anticholinergic agents with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors to prevent adverse effects.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be associated with a falsely elevated SaO2 as measured by pulse oximeter.
questions.solution:
• Carboxyhaemoglobin:
    • Forms when carbon monoxide (CO) binds to haemoglobin, leading to reduced oxygen-carrying capacity.
    • Pulse oximeters using only two wavelengths (660 nm and 940 nm) cannot differentiate between oxyhaemoglobin and carboxyhaemoglobin, resulting in a falsely high SaO2 reading during carbon monoxide poisoning.
  • Methaemoglobin:
    • Absorbs light at both red and infrared wavelengths equally, resulting in a saturation reading of 85% regardless of actual oxygen saturation.
    • Causes a falsely low reading if actual SaO2 > 85% and a falsely high reading if actual SaO2 < 85%.
  • Haemoglobin F:
    • Does not significantly affect pulse oximetry readings and is generally not associated with falsely elevated SaO2.
  • Bilirubin:
    • Has no impact on pulse oximetry and does not affect SaO2 readings.
  • Methylene Blue Dye:
    • Causes a reduction in SaO2 readings due to its absorption characteristics, resulting in a falsely low saturation.

Why Not Others:

  • A: Haemoglobin F does not interfere significantly with pulse oximetry measurements.
  • C: Methylene blue dye lowers the SaO2, not elevates it.
  • D: Bilirubin has no effect on pulse oximetry readings.

Key Takeaways:

  • Carboxyhaemoglobin leads to falsely elevated SaO2 readings on pulse oximetry due to similar light absorption characteristics as oxyhaemoglobin.
  • Understanding Limitations: Awareness of factors that affect pulse oximetry is crucial for accurate assessment, especially in patients with suspected poisoning or underlying hematologic conditions.

questions.text: Allergic reactions occurring during the immediate perioperative period are most commonly attributable to administration of
questions.solution:
• Incidence of Allergic Reactions: Life-threatening anaphylactic or anaphylactoid reactions during anaesthesia occur in approximately 1 in 1,000 to 1 in 25,000 administrations with a mortality rate of about 5%.
  • Common Causes:
    • Neuromuscular blocking agents are reported as the primary cause (58.2%).
    • Other significant causes include latex (16.7%) and antibiotics (15.1%).
  • Mechanisms:
    • Anaphylactic Reactions: Immune-mediated, involving IgE antibodies and mast cells.
    • Anaphylactoid Reactions: Exaggerated pharmacologic responses, not immune-mediated, seen in sensitive individuals.
  • Cross-Reactivity: Neuromuscular blockers can show cross-reactivity with certain foods, cosmetics, and materials.
  • Histamine Release: Steroidal neuromuscular blockers (e.g., rocuronium, vecuronium) do not cause significant histamine release.

Why Not Others:

  • B: Antibiotics can cause allergic reactions but are less common compared to muscle relaxants.
  • C: Allergic reactions to local anaesthetics are rare, with less than 1% of adverse reactions attributed to an allergic mechanism.
  • D: Opioids can cause allergic reactions, but they are not the most common cause in the perioperative setting.

Key Takeaways:

  • Muscle Relaxants: Most frequent cause of allergic reactions during the perioperative period.
  • Emergency Response: In case of anaphylactic reactions, immediate treatment with oxygen and epinephrine is critical, alongside fluid resuscitation.
  • Awareness: Understanding the common allergens can help in risk assessment and management of perioperative allergic reactions.
